pullRequest.body:
We add `fermatLastTheoremWith_of_fermatLastTheoremWith_coprime`: To prove Fermat Last Theorem one can assume that `a`, `b` and `c` are coprime.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: The name should probably be changed. Also, I am not completely sure we want the version for `ℕ` or `ℤ`. Does anyone as an opinion? Do we want both?
I think `hn` is false as stated since you can take `a=1`, `b=0`, `c=1`.

Yes; you need to add the nontriviality condition to `hn`.

As to naturals vs. integers: there could be a general version for unique factorization (semi)rings, which can be specialized to `Nat` (and `Int`).

> Yes; you need to add the nontriviality condition to `hn`.
> 
> As to naturals vs. integers: there could be a general version for unique factorization (semi)rings, which can be specialized to `Nat` (and `Int`).

I guess you could first prove this theorem under general conditions for `FermatLastTheoremWith`, and then specialize to the natural numbers to deduce the result for `FermatLastTheoremFor`.

> I think `hn` is false as stated since you can take `a=1`, `b=0`, `c=1`.

Ops, well spotted!

> Yes; you need to add the nontriviality condition to `hn`.
> 
> As to naturals vs. integers: there could be a general version for unique factorization (semi)rings, which can be specialized to `Nat` (and `Int`).

[Finset.gcd](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/GCDMonoid/Finset.html#Finset.gcd) wants a `NormalizedGCDMonoid`, and in practice this holds very rarely (I don't think we have a reasonable way of getting a semiring with this property, UFD is not enough). I can state the condition by hand though, let me see.

> > Yes; you need to add the nontriviality condition to `hn`.
> > As to naturals vs. integers: there could be a general version for unique factorization (semi)rings, which can be specialized to `Nat` (and `Int`).
> 
> [Finset.gcd](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/GCDMonoid/Finset.html#Finset.gcd) wants a `NormalizedGCDMonoid`, and in practice this holds very rarely (I don't think we have a reasonable way of getting a semiring with this property, UFD is not enough). I can state the condition by hand though, let me see.

Well, it seems to me like a waist of time: what we should to is to remove the `NormalizedGCDMonoid` assumption from the results used here.

> > > Yes; you need to add the nontriviality condition to `hn`.
> > > As to naturals vs. integers: there could be a general version for unique factorization (semi)rings, which can be specialized to `Nat` (and `Int`).
> > 
> > 
> > [Finset.gcd](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/GCDMonoid/Finset.html#Finset.gcd) wants a `NormalizedGCDMonoid`, and in practice this holds very rarely (I don't think we have a reasonable way of getting a semiring with this property, UFD is not enough). I can state the condition by hand though, let me see.
> 
> Well, it seems to me like a waist of time: what we should to is to remove the `NormalizedGCDMonoid` assumption from the results used here.

Now I remember that I have already thought about this: it is not completely trivial, since in reality the `GCD` is only defined up to multiplication by a unit, and in particular it is not really commutative. Annoying...
Wait, `[CommSemiring R] [IsDomain R] [DecidableEq R] [NormalizedGCDMonoid R]` should be ok, I was confused. Let me see and sorry for the noise.

In my private FLT repo I have reduced FLT to (a) FLT for n=3 and (b) non-existence of Frey curve, which contains this result and more as a consequence (I have a,b,c coprime and a=3 mod 4 and b=0 mod 32 or something, whatever one needs to make the curve semistable at 2). But given that we're not going live until April I don't object to this going into mathlib now.

> In my private FLT repo I have reduced FLT to (a) FLT for n=3 and (b) non-existence of Frey curve, which contains this result and more as a consequence (I have a,b,c coprime and a=3 mod 4 and b=0 mod 32 or something, whatever one needs to make the curve semistable at 2). But given that we're not going live until April I don't object to this going into mathlib now.

Don't worry about FLT3, I take responsibility for having it in mathlib before the summer (at least PRed...) but I need this.
I've added the general version for a `NormalizedGCDMonoid`.

> In a `NormalizedGCDMonoid`, a `gcd` is a unit if and only if it equals 1. So you might as well replace the `IsUnit` condition with "equals 1" (which makes the hypothesis `hn` weaker, thereby making the lemma stronger).

Thanks! [normalize_eq_one](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/GCDMonoid/Basic.html#normalize_eq_one) should change name BTW
maintainer merge

bors merge

In a `NormalizedGCDMonoid`, a `gcd` is a unit if and only if it equals 1. So you might as well replace the `IsUnit` condition with "equals 1" (which makes the hypothesis `hn` weaker, thereby making the lemma stronger).

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
I think that's `fermatLastTheoremWith` in a theorem name

```suggestion
    (hn : ∀ a b c : R, a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → c ≠ 0 → ({a, b, c} : Finset R).gcd id = 1 →
```

```suggestion
  simp only [hA, hB, hC, mul_ne_zero_iff, mul_pow] at ha hb hc habc
  rw [← mul_add, mul_right_inj' (pow_ne_zero n ha.1)] at habc
  refine hn A B C ha.2 hb.2 hc.2 ?_ habc
  rw [← Finset.normalize_gcd, normalize_eq_one]
  obtain ⟨u, hu⟩ := normalize_associated d
  refine ⟨u, mul_left_cancel₀ (mt normalize_eq_zero.mp ha.1) (hu.symm ▸ ?_)⟩
  rw [← Finset.gcd_mul_left, gcd_eq_gcd_image, image_insert, image_insert, image_singleton,
      id_eq, id_eq, id_eq, ← hA, ← hB, ← hC]
```

```suggestion
that the `gcd` of `{a, b, c}` is `1`. -/
```

Is there any point keeping these anymore?
```suggestion
/-- To prove Fermat Last Theorem for `ℤ` one can assume that `a`, `b` and `c` are coprime, in the
sense that the gcd of `{a, b, c}` is `1`. -/
lemma FermatLastTheoremWith_int_of_FermatLastTheoremWith_int_coprime {n : ℕ}
    (hn : ∀ a b c : ℤ, a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → c ≠ 0 → ({a, b, c} : Finset ℤ).gcd id = 1 →
      a ^ n + b ^ n ≠ c ^ n) :
    FermatLastTheoremWith ℤ n :=
  fermatLastTheoremWith_of_FermatLastTheoremWith_coprime hn

/-- To prove Fermat Last Theorem one can assume that `a`, `b` and `c` are coprime, in the sense
that the gcd of `{a, b, c}` is `1`. -/
lemma FermatLastTheoremFor_of_FermatLastTheoremFor_coprime {n : ℕ}
    (hn : ∀ a b c, a ≠ 0 → b ≠ 0 → c ≠ 0 → ({a, b, c} : Finset ℕ).gcd id = 1 →
      a ^ n + b ^ n ≠ c ^ n) :
    FermatLastTheoremFor n :=
  fermatLastTheoremWith_of_FermatLastTheoremWith_coprime hn
```
Probably not, you're right. Thanks!

Should this be lowercase as well?
```suggestion
lemma fermatLastTheoremWith_of_fermatLastTheoremWith_coprime {n : ℕ} {R : Type*} [CommSemiring R]
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: add `fermatLastTheoremWith_of_fermatLastTheoremWith_coprime`
